newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia says restructures palm oil export tax.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia says restructures palm oil export tax.

text.p: Indonesia has revised the export tax structure for palm oil under the latest economic deregulation package announced on Monday.
Finance Minister Mar'ie Muhammad said the tax on crude palm oil would be higher than that on processed products.

The government originally introduced the tax in September 1994 to ensure sufficient supply and stable prices in the domestic market. The taxes, announced at the beginning of each month, have been based on a composite average of international prices in the last two weeks of the previous month.

Mar'ie said the export taxes would now be calculated on an ad valorem or in proportion to the estimated value of the goods concerned. He said that during the 1994-1996 period, the export tax on crude palm oil and products ranged between 10 to 12 percent of their export value.
Under the new structure, crude palm oil would be subject to a tax of five percent, RBD palm oil four percent, RBD palm olein two percent and crude olein four percent.
